greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Start with (1, 2, 3); when the sequence has n terms, extend it by appending a(n) copies of a(1..n-1). (Cf. "Look to the left" sequence A293630.)
link: Iain Fox, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: Sequence starts with 1, 2, 3.  Then 3 copies of 1, 2 are appended, giving 1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 2.  Then 2 copies of everything but the final entry 2 are appended, giving 9 + 8 + 8 + 8 = 33 terms.
mathematica: Nest[Join[#, Flatten@ ConstantArray[Drop[#, -1], #[[-1]]] ] &, {1, 2, 3}, 4] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Dec 08 2018 *)
program: (PARI) gen(n, v=[1,2,3], w) = for(x=1, n, w=vector(#v-1, i, v[i]); for(y=1, v[#v], v=concat(v, w))); v
xref: "Look to the left" sequences: A293630 (seed 1,2), A322424 (seed 1,2,3,4), A322425 (seed 1,2,3,4,5).
results.author: _Iain Fox_, Dec 07 2018
ext: Self-contained definition from _M. F. Hasler_, Dec 10 2018
